0202	Present and past	Unit 5: Past simple (<b>I did</b>)	Read about these famous people. Choose the right verb:	Jesse Owens {{c1::was}} a US athlete, born in 1913. He {{c1::died}} in 1980 at the age of 66.	broke / died / lasted / was / won

She {{c1::died}} in France in 1934.	died / discovered / emigrated / was / won				
0204	Present and past	Unit 5: Past simple (<b>I did</b>)	Read about these famous people. Choose the right verb:	Elvis Presley was a rock singer, born in 1935 in Mississippi, USA. His many hits {{c1::included}} Jailhouse Rock, Hound Dog and Blue Suede Shoes. He also {{c1::appeared}} in movies. He {{c1::had}} health problems and in 1977 he {{c1::died}} of a heart attack at the age of 42.	appeared / became / began / died / had / included / taught

Yesterday I got up at about 8 and studied non-stop till 2 in the afternoon.  Then I went out to meet some friends, and we talked and drank coffee together till about 5 o'clock.</p>"

0313	Present and past	Unit 6: Past continuous (<b>I was doing</b>)	Listen to the speakers. Are the statements true or not?	In October he was working in a hotel. {{c1::Not true}}	True / Not true		[sound:006_A_08.mp3]	"<p>I've had three different jobs this year.  I started the year working in a supermarket – that was until April.  I didn't like it very much, so I left. Then I got a job working in a hotel kitchen, but I didn't like that either. I gave that up in September, and immediately started work as a waiter in a restaurant.  And I guess that's OK because it's December now, and I'm still working there.</p>"

Unfortunately, it had been very cold, and the pavement was icy, and I slipped and fell.  I didn't hurt myself badly, but I felt a bit shaken by the experience.</p>"

They're very tall now.}}"	"The trees have grown a lot. So I cut them down. / The trees have grown a lot. They're very tall now."

0652	Present perfect and past 2	Unit 14: Present perfect and past 2 (<b>I have done</b> and <b>I did</b>)	Listen to what Sarah says and choose the correct sentence. "He's never been able to run fast. {{c1::Not true}}<br />He used to be able to run long distances. {{c1::Not true}}<br />He'd like to be able to run a marathon. {{c1::True}}"	True / Not true		[sound:026_B_08.mp3]	"<table border=""0""><tbody><tr><td align=""right"" valign=""top""><span style=""text-align: start;"">A:</span></td><td valign=""top""> </td><td valign=""top"">How do you keep fit?</td></tr><tr><td align=""right"" valign=""top""><span style=""text-align: start;"">B:</span></td><td valign=""top""> </td><td valign=""top"">Running.  I go running every day.</td></tr><tr><td align=""right"" valign=""top""><span style=""text-align: start;"">A:</span></td><td valign=""top""> </td><td valign=""top"">How far do you run?</td></tr><tr><td align=""right"" valign=""top""><span style=""text-align: start;"">B:</span></td><td valign=""top""> </td><td valign=""top"">Not far.  About four kilometres.  I could never run long distances.  I never had the stamina.  I could run quite fast when I was younger but never very far.  Now I can't run far and I can't run fast either.</td></tr><tr><td align=""right"" valign=""top""><span style=""text-align: start;"">A:</span></td><td valign=""top""> </td><td valign=""top"">So you've never run a marathon then.</td></tr><tr><td align=""right"" valign=""top""><span style=""text-align: start;"">B:</span></td><td valign=""top""> </td><td valign=""top"">No, I couldn't do it, which is a shame. It must be great to run a marathon.</td></tr></tbody></table>"

2330	-ing and to 1	Unit 59: <b>prefer</b> and <b>would rather</b>	Use the examples in Exercise 1 to make sentences with <b>prefer to</b> ... <b>rather than</b> ... .	You can say:<br />She prefers going to the cinema to watching movies at home.<br />OR<br /><br />She prefers {{c1::to}} {{c1::go}} {{c1::to the cinema}} {{c1::rather than}} {{c1::watch movies}} {{c1::at home}} (to the cinema / at home / to / rather than / go / watch movies).					
2331	-ing and to 1	Unit 59: <b>prefer</b> and <b>would rather</b>	Use the examples in Exercise 1 to make sentences with <b>prefer to</b> ... <b>rather than</b> ... .	You can say:<br />He prefers being very busy to having nothing to do.<br />OR<br /><br />He prefers {{c1::to}} {{c1::be}} {{c1::very busy}} {{c1::rather}} {{c1::than}} {{c1::have}} {{c1::nothing to do}} (have / than / be / to / nothing to do / very busy / rather).					
2332	-ing and to 1	Unit 59: <b>prefer</b> and <b>would rather</b>	Use the examples in Exercise 1 to make sentences with <b>prefer to</b> ... <b>rather than</b> ... .	You can say:<br />She prefers working with other people to working on her own.<br />OR<br /><br />She prefers {{c1::to}} {{c1::work}} {{c1::with other people}} {{c1::rather}} {{c1::than}} {{c1::on her own}} (rather / to / on her own / work / than / with other people).

3454	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 86: <b>no</b>/<b>none</b>/<b>any</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>nothing</b>/<b>nobody</b> etc	Which is right?	"I'll try and answer {{c1::any}} questions you ask."	any / no

3526	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 87: <b>much</b>, <b>many</b>, <b>a lot</b> etc.	Which is right?	There were {{c1::only a few}} people at the meeting.	only little / only a little / only few / only a few				
3527	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	{{c1::Some films are very violent.}}	Some films are very violent. / Some of films are very violent.				
3528	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	"{{c1::Some of my friends can't come to the party.}}"	"Some my friends can't come to the party. / Some of my friends can't come to the party."				
3529	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	{{c1::Do you want any of these magazines?}}	Do you want any these magazines? / Do you want any of these magazines?				
3530	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	{{c1::Many people drive too fast.}}	Many people drive too fast. / Many of people drive too fast.				
3531	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	{{c1::Kate has lived in London most of her life.}}	Kate has lived in London most her life. / Kate has lived in London most of her life.				
3532	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	"{{c1::Most days I get up before 7 o'clock.}}"	"Most days I get up before 7 o'clock. / Most of days I get up before 7 o'clock."				
3533	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	{{c1::I was sick yesterday. I spent most of the day in bed.}}	I was sick yesterday. I spent most of day in bed. / I was sick yesterday. I spent most of the day in bed.				
3534	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	{{c1::Can I have a little sugar in my coffee?}}	Can I have a little sugar in my coffee? / Can I have a little of sugar in my coffee?				
3535	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	{{c1::I think some people watch too much TV.}}	I think some people watch too much TV. / I think some of people watch too much TV.				
3536	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	"{{c1::I've read a few of these books, but not all of them.}}"	"I've read a few these books, but not all of them. / I've read a few of these books, but not all of them."				
3537	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	{{c1::Last year we spent a few days in London.}}	Last year we spent a few days in London. / Last year we spent a few of days in London.				
3538	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	"{{c1::Most tourists don't come to this part of the town.}}"	"Most tourists don't come to this part of the town. / Most of tourists don't come to this part of the town."				
3539	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Put the words in order.	"They won the lottery a few years ago, but they've {{c1::spent}} {{c1::most}} {{c1::of}} {{c1::the}} {{c1::money}} (most / money / the / of / spent)."					
3540	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Put the words in order.	The weather caused problems at the airport and {{c1::some}} {{c1::flights}} {{c1::were}} {{c1::cancelled}} (cancelled / flights / some / were).					
3541	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Put the words in order.	"It's not a beautiful place, but some {{c1::of}} {{c1::the}} {{c1::city}} {{c1::is}} {{c1::interesting}} (is / of / interesting / city / the)."					
3542	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Put the words in order.	"Sarah has travelled a lot in Europe. She's {{c1::been}} {{c1::to}} {{c1::most}} {{c1::European}} {{c1::countries}} (most / European / to / been / countries)."					
3543	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Put the words in order.	"{Steve and I have different ideas.}<br />I don't {{c1::agree}} {{c1::with}} {{c1::many}} {{c1::of}} {{c1::his}} {{c1::opinions}} (agree / his / many / with / opinions / of)."					
3544	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Put the words in order.	"Nobody knew about the wedding. Emily {{c1::didn't}} {{c1::tell}} {{c1::any}} {{c1::of}} {{c1::her}} {{c1::friends}} (friends / any / her / tell / didn't / of)."					
3545	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Put the words in order.	We argue sometimes, but we {{c1::get on}} {{c1::well}} {{c1::most}} {{c1::of}} {{c1::the}} {{c1::time}} (the / well / time / of / get on / most).					
3546	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Put the words in order.	Music is important to me. I {{c1::like}} {{c1::most}} {{c1::kinds}} {{c1::of}} {{c1::music}} (kinds / music / of / most / like).					
3547	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	"Joe doesn't like museums. He says {{c1::all museums}} are boring."	all of museums / all museums / all the museums				
3548	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	Katherine has lived in Chicago {{c1::all her life}}.	all her life / all the life / all of life				
3549	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	I had no appetite. I could only eat {{c1::half my dinner}}.	half of dinner / the half of my dinner / half my dinner				
3550	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	We lost the game. {{c1::None of the players}} on our team played well.	None the players / None of players / None of the players				
3551	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	Not {{c1::all birds}} can fly. For example, the penguin cannot fly.	all birds / all the birds / all of the birds				
3552	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	The test was hard. I could only answer {{c1::half the questions}}.	half of questions / half the questions / half questions				
3553	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	I went to the cinema by myself. {{c1::None of my friends}} wanted to come.	None of my friend / None of my friends / None my friends				
3554	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Which is right?	"A: Did you spend {{c1::all of the money}} I gave you?<br />B: No, there's some left."	all money / all of money / all of the money				
3555	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Complete the sentences.	We all got wet in the rain because {{c1::none of us}} had an umbrella.	all of it / none of them / some of it / all of them / none of us / none of it / some of them				
3556	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Complete the sentences.	Some of this money is yours and {{c1::some of it}} is mine.	all of it / none of them / some of it / all of them / none of us / none of it / some of them

I asked some people for directions, but {{c1::none of them}} was able to help.	all of it / none of them / some of it / all of them / none of us / none of it / some of them

Most of the tourists in the group were Italian, but {{c1::some of them}} were French.	all of it / none of them / some of it / all of them / none of us / none of it / some of them				
3560	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Complete the sentences.	He told us his life story, but {{c1::none of it}} was true. It was all invented.	all of it / none of them / some of it / all of them / none of us / none of it / some of them				
3561	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 88: <b>some</b> / <b>some of</b> &nbsp;&nbsp; <b>most</b> / <b>most of</b> etc.	Complete the sentences.	"There are no more bananas. We've eaten {{c1::all of them}} ."	all of it / none of them / some of it / all of them / none of us / none of it / some of them				
3562	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 89: <b>both</b>, <b>neither</b> and <b>either</b>	Which is right?	"A: What day is it today, the 18th or 19th?<br />B: {{c1::Neither}}. It's the 20th."	Both / Neither / Either

3564	Pronouns and determiners	Unit 89: <b>both</b>, <b>neither</b> and <b>either</b>	Which is right?	"A: Shall we sit in the corner or by the window?<br />B: {{c1::Either}}. I don't mind."	Both / Neither / Either

It's one of the two.<br /><br />That man's {{c1::name}} {{c1::is}} {{c1::either}} {{c1::Richard}} {{c1::or}} {{c1::Robert}} (is / name / Richard / either / Robert / or)."

3780	Relative clauses	Unit 95: Relative clauses 4: extra information 1	Which sentences are right and which are wrong? Sometimes one is right, sometimes two, and sometimes three.	My office, that is on the second floor, is very small. {{c1::not OK}}<br />My office, which is on the second floor, is very small. {{c1::OK}}<br />My office, who is on the second floor, is very small. {{c1::not OK}}<br />My office, it is on the second floor, is very small. {{c1::not OK}}	OK / not OK				
3781	Relative clauses	Unit 95: Relative clauses 4: extra information 1	Which sentences are right and which are wrong? Sometimes one is right, sometimes two, and sometimes three.	"The office that I'm using at the moment is very small. {{c1::OK}}<br />The office which I'm using at the moment is very small. {{c1::OK}}<br />The office who I'm using at the moment is very small. {{c1::not OK}}<br />The office I'm using at the moment is very small. {{c1::OK}}"	OK / not OK				
3782	Relative clauses	Unit 95: Relative clauses 4: extra information 1	Which sentences are right and which are wrong? Sometimes one is right, sometimes two, and sometimes three.	"Sarah's father, that used to be in the army, now works for a TV company. {{c1::not OK}}<br />Sarah's father, which used to be in the army, now works for a TV company. {{c1::not OK}}<br />Sarah's father, who used to be in the army, now works for a TV company. {{c1::OK}}<br />Sarah's father, whom used to be in the army, now works for a TV company. {{c1::not OK}}"	OK / not OK				
3783	Relative clauses	Unit 95: Relative clauses 4: extra information 1	Which sentences are right and which are wrong? Sometimes one is right, sometimes two, and sometimes three.	"The doctor which examined me couldn't find anything wrong. {{c1::not OK}}<br />The doctor that examined me couldn't find anything wrong. {{c1::OK}}<br />The doctor who examined me couldn't find anything wrong. {{c1::OK}}<br />The doctor whom examined me couldn't find anything wrong. {{c1::not OK}}"	OK / not OK				
3784	Relative clauses	Unit 95: Relative clauses 4: extra information 1	Which sentences are right and which are wrong? Sometimes one is right, sometimes two, and sometimes three. 3785	Relative clauses	Unit 95: Relative clauses 4: extra information 1	Which sentences are right and which are wrong? Sometimes one is right, sometimes two, and sometimes three.	Amy showed me a picture of her son, that is a police officer. {{c1::not OK}}<br />Amy showed me a picture of her son, which is a police officer. {{c1::not OK}}<br />Amy showed me a picture of her son, who is a police officer. {{c1::OK}}<br />Amy showed me a picture of her son, whom is a police officer. {{c1::not OK}}	OK / not OK				
3786	Relative clauses	Unit 95: Relative clauses 4: extra information 1	Which sentences are right and which are wrong? Sometimes one is right, sometimes two, and sometimes three.	Did you find the books you were looking for? {{c1::OK}}<br />Did you find the books that you were looking for? {{c1::OK}}<br />Did you find the books you were looking for them? {{c1::not OK}}<br />Did you find the books which you were looking for? {{c1::OK}}	OK / not OK				
3787	Relative clauses	Unit 95: Relative clauses 4: extra information 1	Which sentences are right and which are wrong? Sometimes one is right, sometimes two, and sometimes three. 3788	Relative clauses	Unit 95: Relative clauses 4: extra information 1	Which sentences are right and which are wrong? Sometimes one is right, sometimes two, and sometimes three.	Do you know anyone who speaks French and Italian? {{c1::OK}}<br />Do you know anyone that speaks French and Italian? {{c1::OK}}<br />Do you know anyone whom speaks French and Italian? {{c1::not OK}}<br />Do you know anyone speaks French and Italian? {{c1::not OK}}	OK / not OK

"Kate's husband, that I've never met, is an airline pilot. {{c1::not OK}}<br />Kate's husband, who I've never met, is an airline pilot. {{c1::OK}}<br />Kate's husband, I've never met, is an airline pilot. {{c1::not OK}}<br />Kate's husband, whom I've never met, is an airline pilot. {{c1::OK}}"	OK / not OK

4321	Adjectives and adverbs 2	Unit 110: Word order 2: adverbs with the verb	Which is right?	{{c1::Amy is always very busy.}}	Amy always is very busy. / Amy is always very busy.

4323	Adjectives and adverbs 2	Unit 110: Word order 2: adverbs with the verb	Which is right?	{{c1::Steve is very calm. He hardly ever gets angry.}}	Steve is very calm. He gets hardly ever angry. / Steve is very calm. He hardly ever gets angry.				
4324	Adjectives and adverbs 2	Unit 110: Word order 2: adverbs with the verb	Which is right?	{{c1::When I arrived, my friends were already there.}}	When I arrived, my friends were already there. / When I arrived, my friends already were there.				
4325	Adjectives and adverbs 2	Unit 110: Word order 2: adverbs with the verb	Which is right?	"{{c1::There's always somebody in this cafe. It's never empty.}}"	"There's always somebody in this cafe. It never is empty. / There's always somebody in this cafe. It's never empty."				
4326	Adjectives and adverbs 2	Unit 110: Word order 2: adverbs with the verb	Which is right?	{{c1::I usually sleep about six hours a night.}}	I sleep usually about six hours a night. / I usually sleep about six hours a night.				
4327	Adjectives and adverbs 2	Unit 110: Word order 2: adverbs with the verb	Which is right?	"{{c1::It's usually easy to find a hotel room here.}}"	"It's usually easy to find a hotel room here. / It usually is easy to find a hotel room here."				
4328	Adjectives and adverbs 2	Unit 110: Word order 2: adverbs with the verb	Which is right?	{{c1::It was raining and it was also very cold.}}	It was raining and it also was very cold. / It was raining and it was also very cold.				
4329	Adjectives and adverbs 2	Unit 110: Word order 2: adverbs with the verb	Which is right?	{{c1::I called them and I also sent an email.}}	I called them and I also sent an email. / I called them and I sent also an email.				
4330	Adjectives and adverbs 2	Unit 110: Word order 2: adverbs with the verb	Put the words in order.	Lisa is a good pianist. She {{c1::can}} {{c1::also}} {{c1::sing}} (also / sing / can) very well.

4332	Adjectives and adverbs 2	Unit 110: Word order 2: adverbs with the verb	Put the words in order.	"The journey took a long time today. It {{c1::doesn't}} {{c1::always}} {{c1::take}} (take / always / doesn't) so long."

I'll never stay there again. / The hotel we stayed in was awful. I never will stay there again."

But if the weather is bad, this may not be possible. {{c1::I'm playing tennis tomorrow unless the weather is bad.}}"	"I'm playing tennis tomorrow unless the weather is bad. / I'm not playing tennis tomorrow unless the weather is bad."

You have to talk to him, or he won't say anything. {{c1::Ben won't speak to you unless you ask him something.}}"	"Ben will speak to you unless you ask him something. / Ben won't speak to you unless you ask him something."

"was / didn't get / got"		[sound:120_B_11.mp3]	"<p>My train was delayed last night.  It was supposed to get here at 10.30, but it was two hours late.  I finally got home at 1 o'clock. </p>"

"The meeting was supposed to start at 9.30, but nearly everybody was late.<br /><br />By {{c1::the time}} {{c1::the meeting}} {{c1::started}} (the meeting / started / the time), it was nearly 10 o'clock."

5693	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Put the words in order.	"I'd like to go out tonight, but I have a lot of things to do.<br />I'd go out tonight {{c1::if}} {{c1::I}} {{c1::didn't}} {{c1::have}} {{c1::so}} {{c1::much}} {{c1::to}} {{c1::do}} (much / do / I / have / if / to / didn't / so)."					
5694	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Put the words in order.	"I had to make a difficult decision. I don't know if it was right.<br />If you'd been in my position, {{c1::what}} {{c1::would}} {{c1::you}} {{c1::have}} {{c1::done}} (you / what / done / have / would)?"					
5695	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Put the words in order.	"There are many accidents on this road. There is no speed limit.<br />If there was a speed limit on this road, {{c1::there}} {{c1::wouldn't}} {{c1::be}} {{c1::so}} {{c1::many}} {{c1::accidents}} (many / there / accidents / so / be / wouldn't)."					
5696	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Put the words in order.	"I didn't call you because I didn't have my phone with me.<br />I'd have called you {{c1::if}} {{c1::I'd}} {{c1::had}} {{c1::my}} {{c1::phone}} {{c1::with}} {{c1::me}} (my / had / with / me / I'd / if / phone)."					
5697	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Put the words in order.	"We managed to put the fire out quickly, so there wasn't much damage.<br />If we hadn't put the fire out quickly, {{c1::there}} {{c1::could}} {{c1::have}} {{c1::been}} {{c1::a lot}} {{c1::of}} {{c1::damage}} (could / damage / there / a lot / been / of / have)."					
5698	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Which is right?	"I didn't realise you were waiting for me. If {{c1::I'd known}}, I would have got here earlier."	"I knew / I'd known / I would know / I'd have known"				
5699	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Which is right?	You watch TV a lot. What {{c1::would you do}} if there was no TV?	do you do / did you do / would you do / will you do				
5700	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Which is right?	"I can't decide what to do. What would you do if {{c1::you were}} me?"	"you would be / you are / you'd been / you were"				
5701	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Which is right?	"A: What shall we do tomorrow?<br />B: Well, if {{c1::it's}} a nice day, we can go to the beach."	"it was / it will be / it's / it would be"				
5702	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Which is right?	"A: Let's go to the beach.<br />B: No, it's not warm enough. If {{c1::it was}} warmer, I'd go."	"it was / it would be / it's / it had been"				
5703	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Which is right?	A: Did you go to the beach yesterday?<br />B: No, it was too cold. If {{c1::it had been}} warmer, we might have gone.	it was / it would be / it would have been / it had been				
5704	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Which is right?	If {{c1::you had}} enough money to go anywhere in the world, where would you go?	"you would have / you had / you'd had / you would have had"				
5705	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Which is right?	"The accident was your fault. If you {{c1::had been driving}} more carefully, it wouldn't have happened."	would drive / would have driven / had been driving / have been driving				
5706	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Which is right?	"A: Why do you watch the TV news? <br />B: Well, if I {{c1::didn't watch}} the news, I wouldn't know what was happening in the world."	"didn't watch / hadn't watched / wouldn't watch / don't watch"				
5707	Additional Exercises	<b>if</b> ... (Units 38–40)	Which is right?	This city would be more pleasant if {{c1::there were}} more parks and open spaces.	there are / there were / there would be / there had

Two people {{c1::are reported to have been injured}} in an explosion at a factory in Birmingham early this morning.	are reported to have injured / reported to be injured / are reported to have been injured / have reported to be injured
